awd_titl_txt: CRII: CIF: Secret Sharing Under Communication Constraints in Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
As wireless networks become ubiquitous, the ability to maintain trust and securely exchange confidential information among interconnected wireless devices and users is crucial. Secret sharing is a cryptographic primitive that can help to achieve secure communication with applications that include access control, key management, digital signatures, and others. Although this primitive is widely used, it is still not fully understood how wireless communication constraints such as noise, limited bandwidth, and scalability can be optimally accounted for in the design of secret sharing schemes. This project aims for new guidelines for the implementation of secret sharing directly adapted to wireless communication constraints, to improve security for users, minimize the communication cost associated with the implementation, and facilitate deployment in dense wireless networks through improved scalability.

Most existing secret sharing schemes hinge on the assumption that the dealer can securely communicate the shares of the secret to the participants over noiseless channels with unlimited bandwidth. Under such an assumption, the implementation of secret sharing schemes in wireless networks requires additional layers of protocols able to deal with unsecured, noisy, and bandwidth limited communication channels between the dealer and the participants. The objective of this project is to understand whether such a layered approach is optimal and whether a scheme that simultaneously addresses the constraints of wireless communication and the requirements of secret sharing could provide gains in terms of communication efficiency and security guarantees. The project investigates two interdependent research tasks: (i) understanding the fundamental security limits for secret sharing in wireless networks under bandwidth constraints and noise, and (ii) the design of explicit low-complexity coding schemes using tools from cryptography and coding theory.
This award is jointly funded by the Division of Computing and Communication Foundations in the Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research in the Office of Integrative Activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on understanding the fundamental security limits of secret sharing in wireless networks. While secret sharing has mainly been studied using cryptographic tools and models that ignore wireless communication specificities such as the noisy, open, and bandwidth-limited nature of wireless channels, the project aimed to better understand secret sharing via a complementary perspective tailored to wireless communication. Specifically, in contrast to the traditional and purely cryptographic view, our approach aimed at directly integrating wireless communication constraints in our models.

The main intellectual highlights of this project include: (i) determining fundamental limits of secret sharing from correlated random variables and public communication, in particular, the best possible achievable performances in terms of security guarantees, communication cost, and scalability; (ii) proposing novel coding techniques that enable constructive and low-complexity coding schemes for secret sharing under wireless communication constraints. Beyond the application to secret sharing, the coding techniques developed in this project also enable explicit low-complexity coding schemes that guarantee information-theoretic security in communication problems that had either no known constructive solutions or only non-optimal constructive solutions. Examples of such information-theoretic problems include multiple-access channel resolvability, compound secret-key generation, and a wide range of wiretap channel models. 

Educational outreach activities included undergraduate research projects on secret-key generation with information-theoretic security.

Human resource development and training outcomes of this research included training two female Ph.D. students in information theory, cryptography,  and wireless communications.
